subject: Re: [junit] Problems with assertEquals...
msgSnippet: We had the same problem testing classes where dates were being written to and retrieved from a database. Typically, objects were being saved with a created
messageBody:
We had the same problem testing classes where dates were being written
to and retrieved from a database. Typically, objects were being saved
with a "created" Date. We ended up having to pass the date to the
methods in question instead of instantiating the date inside the method
in order to test effectively. Our whitebox tests with mocks were usually
succeeding, but the live integration tests with the database failed.
Somehow it seems like a code smell, but fudging the comparison of two
dates to ignore the milliseconds didn't seem right either.

John

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>Lewis, Grant wrote:
>
>
>
>>It was the stupid milliseconds. I called toString() to compare the date
>>strings instead of comparing the objects. The database load caused a
>>millisecond mismatch with the original that was saved.
>>
>>
--
